Subject: Facial Recognition Assistance Good afternoon, My name is Ernie Butner and I am a paralegal with the Middlesex District Attorney’s Office. I hopethis email finds you well. It is my understanding that the RMV has the capability of cross-referencing images with the RMVdatabase of photos in order to help law enforcement agencies identify unknown suspects. We havea case out of   in which we have surveillance images of a suspect but no identification,and we were hoping to make use of this facial recognition software if possible. I have attached several stills from the surveillance image to this email. Can you please tell me if youare able to run facial recognition and, if so, whether or not these photos will suffice for this purpose? Thank you very much. If you have any questions or concerns, or need any clarification, please feelfree to let me know. Best,Ernie The preceding email message (including any attachments) contains information that may be confidential, may be protectedby the attorney-client or other applicable privileges, or may constitute non-public information. Subject: RFAAttachments: .pdfGood Evening, I received a request for assistance from our ICE office at the US Embassy in    The attachedDLs are people attempting to get   version of a Social Security Number, which would allowthem to open bank accounts, apply for visas, and customs paperwork. I looked at the   and immediately knew they were fake since the license number on somestarted with other letters than S, and also had too many numbers.  I ran the names DOB and gotnothing in CJIS and III. I was hoping to run FR on all of the attached licenses and see if we can get any hits back. ICE is working a theory this is a ID fraud case. Please let me know if you have any other questions. Thank You,Brian Brian E. Subject: Facial RecognitionHello! Could you please run facial recognition between two licenses to determine if they are the sameperson?  This is for DEA Narcotics Case #  (Cocaine). License  ID  These names both hit on the same III record and there is a strong resemblance between the twophotos given aging over a period of 15 years.  I am trying to identify if they are the same person. Thank you!Paul Donnelly

to: Donnelly, Paul D; MSP-DL - Facial Rec ES
body: Subject: RE: Facial RecognitionPaul, We have reviewed your request.  Facial Rec did not hit the two photos.However, after inspecting the two images I agree with your assessment these are one and the sameperson.  In my opinion there are a couple of reasons why the system did not hit on these photos.  Ifyou would like to discuss this please do not hesitate to call me. Respectfully,Detective Stephen Walker #2033Massachusetts State PoliceFraud Identification UnitCriminal Information and Intelligence SectionDivision of Homeland Security PreparednessTen Park PlazaBoston, MA. 02116Offic 26Cell: Fax: 1Fax2: 1-857-368-0649Stephen.Walker@DOT.state.ma.usThe preceding email message (including any attachments) contains information thatmay be confidential, may be protected by the attorney-client or other applicableprivileges, or may constitute non-public information. Subject: Facial recognition requestTo Whom It May Concern:   I’m reaching out to request assistance with any facial recognition process you might be able toemploy to help with an on-going HSI investigation.   Through my investigation, I’ve identified a subject who may be obtaining driver’s licenses usingboth his real name and date of birth, and fictitious names and associated biographical information.   I have three (3) different photos of the same subject found on various driver’s licenses which I haveattached to this email.  I’m hoping you might be able to run these against any facial recognitiondatabase to which you have access.   Any help you might be able to provide would be hugely appreciated.  Please do not hesitate tocontact me by cell or email to clarify the nature of the request, or if any specific form ordocumentation is required in order to respond to this request.  My case and agency information is below, in the event you need it for bookkeeping: Case number:    Subject name:                                   Agency ORI:        Case type:           Financial fraud - 18 USC 1028A (Agg. ID Theft); 1029 (Access Device Fraud); 1030(Fraudulent use of a computer); 1343 (Wire Fraud); 1956(a)(1)(b) (Money laundering)  Respectfully,

Subject: [Probable Spam] RE: Previous identified Impostor with valid Mass License who wasidentified by Lowell PD Det. Burd has made it back into U.S. after deportation. Jimmy, Is there an image of a seal anywhere on this document?  We just identified a subject here in Ohio,going through our counterparts in PR… (see attached).  Even the PR guys said it was  a pretty goodforgery. We are working a case now with the Ohio BMV, and our DBFTF, with direct ties to your area… can’tgive a lot of details, but we’ve arrested 3 this week, identified a handful of others, and sent Kathysome id’s to de-conflict.  She’s finding lots of impostors up your way… MA, MD, NJ, NY… Thank you, Bradley A. Subject: Previous identified Impostor with valid Mass License who was identified by Lowell PD Det.Burd has made it back into U.S. after deportation. ​     Hi Team, nice grab here by State Police out in Sturbridge during a traffic stop last Fridaynight. They were not fooled by the pretty good fraudulent "Real ID" Puerto Rico license.Running that OLN does come back to a PR License under that same Name however the Dob isdifferent. They were also able to get a facial recognition hit using our Fusion Center. TheFusion Center did a nice job getting a hit on two of his previous Mass Licenses under Impostoridentities. I hope the Fusion Center is thinking of rolling all our arrest/booking photos fromAFISR into the same facial recognition data base! Imagine this same type of data base NewEngland wide! This would be very bad for the bad guys! The access to this type of "ThirdThumb Print" my new term, roadside would be amazing. When me and Kathy saw the licensephoto we knew we has seen this Impostor before and "ICE Man Craig Hamel" recognized himright away as someone he had deported last year.     His real name is   and Lowell still had a felony trafficking warrant out for hisarrest. This works out very well when the DA's office does not dismiss the drug case justbecause the suspect has been deported. All of this gave the Troopers more than enough totake this known impostor into custody. I'm hoping the Secure Communities alarm went offand he was grabbed the following Monday in court. The obvious questions is how was he ableto easily make it back into the U.S.? Does his employer, the drug cartel have a clear path ofentry we don't know about? He would make a great interview. This Lowell case was also oneof our first facial recognition hits using the agencies assigned to the Dominican Rep. Again, thisis the same facial recognition the ACLU and Somerville don't want us using! Are we really thatconcerned about these drug dealers alleged rights? James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PDIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program "Identifying the Impostor".

Subject: Fw: Francisco Gabriel Velez VegaAttachments: S4 .jpgPR License Front.jpgPR License Back.jpgPR RMW Result .pngGood Morning Lt. Boyle,Just passing this information along regarding a motor vehicle stop I had this past week, duringwhich time Fusion Center assisted me.  I was presented with a PR Driver's License and Social Security Card by the rear seat passengeridentified as   (DOB:  , SS# ).  A CJIS queryof the SS# revealed another party with the same name, DOB, and SS#.  A III query revealedtwo different FBI numbers.  At that point, I believed I had an "Impostor" situation.  I reachedout to the Fusion Center for assistance with facial recognition, who provided various OLNsbased upon the facial recognition hits.  These OLNS are listed below and reflect the sameparty using different names, DOBs, and SS#:I then received an email from PR Police Department, which matched the PR License holder Ihad on the stop.  Therefore, I kicked him loose, believing the passenger may have been thevictim of the Impostor, to which he no knowledge.  Attached in this email are the RMV photos from PR and MA, as well as the PR License thepassenger possessed.  Another flag that caught my eye was the PR License itself.  The licenseissue date was 03/21/2017.  I have a PDF Document from the Fraud Department in NYPD,which covers PR Licenses issued in 2019.  I noted a few indicators of a potentially forgedRMV document (missing gold star upper right hand corner, "Not for Real ID Purposes" was notomitted, "Commonwealth of Puerto Rico" rather than "Government of Puerto Rico", and thelisted height and weight were typed without hyphens.  I'm not sure if the PR licenses issued in 2017 printed with different security measures, but itcame back valid from PR RMV.  I believe the passenger I had roadside was the victim basedupon the multiple OLNs used by the same party out of Lawrence, the passenger was able toanswer all roadside questions about Puerto Rico, and his finger prints were not mutilated.Please let know if you have any questions or need anything further.Respectfully,Tpr. Daniel Lawlor #4160Massachusetts State PoliceSP Charlton

Subject: The Rhode Island SP impostor arrest wanted out of RI with a valid MA License also had a valid U.S. Passport​     Hi Team, nice heads up by Jacqueline Frederick out of the Boston State Dept Office. Shetook a look at the arrest made by RISP and queried the names used by the Impostor and got ahit on a valid U.S. Passport. When we talk to each other the bad guys suffer, that is why yourreports are so important, yup, talking about you Quincy!!     Your reports go to all the other approximate 1800 students, our RMV, State IG, State ID,Border Patrol all over the place, NYPD, Texas, Louisiana, State Dept, EBT, numerous RMV's andDMV's up and down the coast.     You can get on any plane at any airport with a valid U.S. Passport. James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PDIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program "Identifying the Impostor".

Subject: RE: Rhode Island SP impostor arrest wanted out of RI with a valid MA License, slightvariation here. Good Morning Jimmy, I was just taking a look at the article you sent out. Looks like this individual also applied and wasissued a U.S. Passport in the   identity in 2015. My office would be very interested inadding on some federal passport charges if possible. I have CC’ed SA Pete Brady. He will be the agentworking the case from our side. Would you be able to get us in contact with Trooper Shaw? Thank you, Jackie  Jacqueline FrederickInvestigative SpecialistBoston Field OfficeDiplomatic Security ServiceDepartment of StateFrederickJM@state.gov617-565-8943    SBUOfficial - SBU UNCLASSIFIED

<John.Meyers@massmail.state.ma.us>; George Xenakis-Mass OIG Dep Dir(George.Xenakis@massmail.state.ma.us) <George.Xenakis@massmail.state.ma.us>; Kevin Floster(kevin.floster@state.ma.us) <kevin.floster@state.ma.us>; Logan Davis (logan.r.davis@state.ma.us)<logan.r.davis@state.ma.us>Subject: Rhode Island SP impostor arrest wanted out of RI with a valid MA License, slight variationhere.      Hi Team, nice arrest here by Trp Shaw out of Rhode Island State Police. He hit right away onthe key indicator of that license at age 29 and then the driver not knowing anything about hisprior Puerto Rico living history. Access to the Puerto Rico license data base then only madething worse for him. The slight variation here is using the real but fraudulently obtained MassLicense while trying to hide from his gun charges and warrant in Rhode Island. You can alsosee that he had a prior Rhode Island license number. Imagine the results of just a New Englandfacial recognition program never mind tossing the Puerto Rico DMV data base into thatsearch. I know, you have heard it before. "Jimmy, We can't be arresting thousands of herointraffickers for license fraud and identity theft." PS- Trp Garrett Hassett taught Trp Shaw everything he knows! James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PDIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program "Identifying the Impostor".

body: Subject: RE: Request Facial Req searchGood Afternoon Sir, Facial Recognition was ran on the photo you provided and resulted in a possible match to: DOB SS# MA LIC# LKA –   01105 Please be advised that the picture you will see on CJIS was imaged on 12-10-1997. This license hasbeen expired since 9-25-2002. The image in CJIS is the only one we have on file. In my professional opinion, given the varying aging effect of a Hispanic male, I believe the facialbiometrics in the given pictures present enough of a resemblance that a reasonable person wouldbelieve the persons depicted may be one in the same and therefore further investigation iswarranted. *Disclaimer: The result of a face recognition search is provided by the FIU only as an investigativelead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT. Any possibleconnection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must be determined through furtherinvestigation.* Respectfully Submitted, Tpr. Danny Malhotra #3642    Massachusetts State PoliceDivision of Homeland Security and PreparednessFraud Identification Unitnd10 Park Plaza 2  FloorBoston, MA 02116danish.malhotra2@dot.state.ma.usOffice: (857) 368-9500Desk: (857) 368-8622Cell: (857)-324-0411Fax: (857) 368-0649

to: Salvatore, Justin (POL); Oley, Carl (POL); Brooks, Brian (POL); Huber, Richard (POL); Boyle, Christopher (POL);
body: Thibault, Amy (POL); Smith, Eleanor (POL); O"Leary, Sarah (POL)Subject: RE: Possible Fraudulent Identification - Request for Facial Recognition - DEA Boston OfficeAttachments: image001.pngUpon reviewing the below email, it was discovered that a case already exists with our office, FRCase#   and MSP Case#  . There were no additional licenses/IDsdiscovered other than what is in the case and the same 4 license numbers listed below in the email.Here are the findings from the case: · All 4 licenses have been suspended/revoked for fraud.         · The true   living in IL sent proof and obtained a Letter of Clearance from         our RMV Office.· A criminal complaint was filed in 2010 by Tpr. Campinha under the MSP report, using John         Doe and the 4 aliases as AKA’s, but warrant is no longer active. Court decision in 2018 was a“NO PROS” by ADA. Unknown who showed up to court that day. Courts had no furtherinformation.· SA Jason Froio (617-565-8200) from Diplomatic Security Office looked into this person on 4-         5-07.· SA Dana Fiandaca (617-828-4571) from ICE had FR ran on a pic that matched with our         suspect on 1-26-12.· SA Craig Hamel (781-420-1030) from ICE/ERO had FR ran on one of the license (S08971745)         pics that matched with our suspect on 4-17-15. Suspect is a 3 time re-entry illegal immigrant. Respectfully, Chris Lieutenant Christopher Boyle #2710Massachusetts State PoliceDivision of Homeland Security and PreparednessFraud Identification Unitnd10 Park Plaza, 2  FloorBoston, MA  02116christopher.boyle@mass.govcell: 781-738-7286

Please let us know if you need any additional assistance.
 
Respectfully,
Justin
 
Justin Salvatore
Intelligence Analyst II
Massachusetts State Police | Commonwealth Fusion Center
470 Worcester Road, Framingham, MA 01702

Within ISO, there was one insurance claim from September 2017 involving thesubject. That report is attached as well. The photo of your subject (the one you arrested) was also runthrough facial recognition.   has a DL history under that name/photo since at least around 2013 inMassachusetts. I sent her all of the information and as soon asI get word from her, I will let you know. Eleven (11) of those arrests were made after he intentionally mutilated his fingerprints in anattempt to hide his identity. First arrest with mutilated fingerprints 1/18/2006.On February 18, 2019, we became aware of his mutilated fingerprints. At that time they werenot linked with the non-mutilated files. He was added to our list of files with Mutilatedfingerprints - #779We searched them as latent prints and located two (2) addition files with the earlier arrestswith non-mutilated prints. The files were merged. We only located one (1) BOP record PCF:00002792088. There may be others that we couldnot find. Contact BOP for help with that. Attached please find Personal Summary showing the mutilated prints and the Mass RAP sheet.That is all we have at this time. Subject: Tewksbury PD arrest impostor using real but fraudulently obtained FL License to conceal his real ID andtrafficking warrant.Attachments: Tewksbury Impostor arrest 6-19-2019  .pdf​​     Hi Team, nice pinch here by Tewksbury PD and they all applied a number of the programsconcept very well. Note they were not fooled by the Florida License (    and howthey checked his finger print results giving them his real ID and Lowell trafficking warrant (-  This report will be sent to our MSP Division of Homeland Security andPreparedness Fraud Identification Unit, use to be called RMV Compliance and I'm betting hehas a number of "flagged" identities in their data base and their facial recognition wascatching him forcing him to go out of State for another license. We love those out of Statelicenses!     Also note the assist from PR PD on finding the true number holder/PR License bearer.Hopefully we can make contact with the TNH and notify him of his stolen identity. Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFRIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying theImpostor".

body: (DOT)Subject: Norwood MA PD search warrant and Impostor arrest-"Clean Package" Triple I but "Dirty Package" for obtainingMass LicenseAttachments: Search warrant completed.pdfId Fraud Affidavit for documents.docxNorwood Impostor Christopher Piris-Clean Package III Dirty Package for MA RMV.pdf     Hi Team, nice arrest and search warrant here by Off Diego Silva of Norwood PD. This guy was on their radar forsometime and they were able to build enough PC for the arrest and search warrant. Lot of material here so take youtime. Note what happened to the stolen identity he purchased. It was good for there being no one in Triple I with thatName, Dob and SSN until he was arrested and booked by Boston PD in 2012 and for what? Class A trafficking atage giving us "0-100" "LONSHP" and "Dude dropped from the sky." The last page in the package, the RMV R1shows you a "REV" license using the same Name, Dob and SSN however the picture is of a different guy and thatwas back in 2011. It looks like the Norwood-Piris bought a Lemon. Someone already had tried that identity at theRMV in Mass and was rejected perhaps by a document scanner. Again, no arrest were made, just the wannabeImpostor's money was taken and he was given a temporary paper license.     We are still working this guy, he had been submitted for  DR Facial Recognition and he has a "5 Digit" FBINumber. "Jimmy, you never mentioned a 5 Digit FBI Number in the class?"  Correct, just not enough time to coverespecially what we do in Phase Two. But, in the past sometimes a 5 Digit FBI Number-His- (18645PD2)has beenfound to be older than a 6 Digit FBI Number (123456AB1) and that sometimes when his scanned finger prints aresent to ICE they find an older record on him that we can't see. Sort of like an invisible FN or AR number. He alsospent 3 years in MCI here in Mass so he has a lot of info/intel in InMate Web that we are looking at. You have noidea how important phone numbers and addresses can be. Especially phone numbers, if everyone started addingthose during the booking process that would be huge.Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFRIdentityTheft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying theImpostor".

Subject: Brockton, Newton and now Boston PDs: Fraudulent Jeep Purchases with False Puerto Rican License - Arrests andRecoveries     Hi Team, some great work coming your way regarding "Retail Impostors" and the latestvictimization of real identities of US Citizens (USC's) from Puerto Rico with Good CreditRatings! In order to pull off these coming examples not only do you need to steal a realidentity but the Complete Package also has to have good enough credit to allow the bad guyto be handed the keys to a brand new $65,000 Jeep. This Retail Impostor also applies to thecrew down on the South Shore and Rhode Island who were using real identities and openingup Home Depot accounts. I never did hear where those real identities came from. Someoneneeds to develop a system combining law enforcement, RMV/DMV and Credit Companiesdata bases combined and have a product that can vet a Driver's License or State ID on thespot. Banks, retail and now dealerships are getting beat. Imagine if this is what finally fixes allof this fraud, not all the drugs, fatal overdoses and stolen benefits along with voting, but themassive finacial loss of big business. Hmmmm     Reports to follow, below is the well done summary by Chris Neville from the Mass FusionCenter. Attached documents are from Off Chris Perez and Jason Sullivan who did a nice job onthis case. So far there has been one copy cat out of Boston PD only a few days after theNewton and Brockton incidents.Off. James Scott, Saugus MA PD, Ret-SMSgt, Security Forces, USAFRIdentityTheft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program called "Identifying theImpostor".
Subject: [Probable Spam] Brockton and Newton PDs: Fraudulent Jeep Purchases with False PuertoRican License - Arrests and Recoveries                                Attention: New England Wide-

Subject: Brockton and Newton PD: Fraudulent Jeep Purchases with False Puerto Rican ID –
Arrests and Recoveries
-
Synopsis:
-
[On 1-15-19 an individual using a Counterfeit Puerto Rican License and Utility Bills showing
a Fall River Address was able to purchase and finance a new Jeep from McGovern Jeep in
Newton. Subject showed identification in the name of  , DOB
. Subject was approved for financing and drove the vehicle off the lot and apparently had it immediately registered.  
-
On 1-16-19, the same individual using the same identification and documents attempted to
purchase a new 2019 Jeep from Jeep 24 in Brockton. The suspect left the facility while the
financing was being approved and was to return when the financing was completed.  The
Financing Company noted the prior approval and determined that both applications were
fraudulent.  Brockton Police were notified and when the suspect was called back to pick up
the Jeep, he was arrested for identity fraud and attempted larceny.  He was subsequently
identified as  ,  , most recently of    Cruz had three active
warrants and claimed to have a   NH address. 
-
On 1-17-19, Methuen Police received a report of a GPS hit that the stolen “Newton” Jeep
was currently on East St. Officers located the Jeep and found a subject in the driver’s seat
who identified himself as  . He was subsequently arrested. During the
booking process he was positively identified as   ,  showing a 
 address.
During an inventory search, a “box” was found containing materials used to fabricate
identification cards.
-
these may not be the only two vehicles purchased
Secondary information indicates that  .  
Facial Recognition will be run on both individuals.
DHS/ICE is also investigating ]

body: Center (POL)Subject: RE: Facial recognition Good afternoon. Are you working with another agency onthis facial recognition? When I ran the picture with the threegentlemen in it through facial recognition, I came up with apossible match. I ran the middle person through facialrecognition. He also came up in Coplink with a potentialmatch to the same person. It looks like this person has awarrant for assault with intent to murder. I ran his RMVpictures through facial recognition too to see if there wereother aliases. Please let me know what you think. Thanks.

body: Subject: Re: Request for   etc from PR for possible fraud licenses.Hey Erin,So I haven’t had a chance to take a closer look yet, but I intend to. At first glance I believeeither all or most are fraudulent. All these cases are State to State cases meaning someone elseis the US is using the same info and an alert was made by the computer system theDMVs/RMVs use, so we have to verify whether we have the real person here or the imposter.I completely understand that it will take a while because of the amount of people, totallyunderstand that, no worries. I will send the info to you tomorrow. ThanksSent from my iPhoneOn Mar 20, 2019, at 9:01 AM, Dolan, Erin <Erin.Dolan@ice.dhs.gov> wrote:Hey Danny I will have to send a lead to Puerto Rico for a query of this size, so it may take sometime. I have seen   before, possibly in connection with a corrupt clerkcase.  Is there anything in his record about that?  Can you see what clerk issued it?Also,   has a US passport.  If you believe he submitted fraudulent docs, weare going to have to open a case.  I attached the passport app with electoral card hesubmitted to State. Can you send the documents he submitted to the RMV so we canlook a little closer at that one? In the meantime, I can send a request to Puerto Rico for DAVIDs. Were these run against the RMV facial recognition system?  It looks like quite a few of these are still in statute, maybe we can work together toidentify them? Erin

The names listed below have all presented possiblefraudulent docs to include PR Birth Certs to obtain MA licenses and the same hasoccurred in another state. I arrested an individual recently(see attachment) andhe had some identity issues. I'm interested in using his booking photo in facial recognitionthrough the RMV to try and locate any other fraud ID's he might be using. Are you familiarwith that process or do you know who can help me accomplish that mission?  Paul Martin #3646Trooper D-4Massachusetts State Police326 West Grove StreetMiddleboro,MA 02346Tel: 508-947-2222Fax: 508-923-4115 CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE  The information contained in this email and any attachment is privileged and confidential lawenforcement information. He is no longer under supervision but we have a ton of his previous identities.  His casewas prosecuted in the District of NH and we did supervision for them.  Interesting case though, he wascharged with new offenses while on supervision and the state dismissed those charges and he was alsothe victim of an armed home invasion in Fitchburg.  See identifiers and docs below....  Also, the AUSA inNH thought he was   of the D.R., brother of previously deported  .  He alsoallegedly had a minor son (about age 7 in 2010)  , with a  . He denied all that and came up with other names along the way for himself and his son!!

Subject: SECURE: CFC Pass-Through: RIFC (U//LES) Request for Information: Regional Fraud Investigation - Non-UrgentAttachments: U-LES RIFC 2019-8 RFI   Regional Fraud Investigation.pdfBulletin Type: Information Request - New  Status:  Active Narrative:(U//LES) Please find the attached bulletin created by and distributed on behalf of the RhodeIsland State Fusion Center. The Rhode Island State Police is investigating an elderly“grandson in jail” scam where an out of state elderly victim sent $5,200 in cash via UPSshipment to Rhode Island. During the investigation, police discovered two involved suspectswith ties to New Jersey, New York, and Southern New England, who utilized false names anddates of birth, including a legitimate “impostor” identification, to mask their identity.(U//LES)  , DOB:   has criminal ties to NJ, NY, MA and RI and wasrecently arrested in Cranston, Rhode Island for breaking into vehicles. It is believed thatQUESADA is involved in multiple fraudulent schemes where his revolving identity has aidedhim in avoiding appropriate prosecution. (U//LES)  , DOB:   hascriminal ties to CT, RI and MA and was recently taken into custody by RISP attempting toretrieve the cash at a local UPS store. Both subjects were in possession of fraudulent NewJersey Identification, which was utilized to enhance the scheme. The pair were observedoperating in a 2005 Toyota Sienna Minivan, color blue, bearing Massachusetts Registration8LL486. Police Departments are requested to review any cases with similar suspects oractivities to share information regarding these suspects for possible federal prosecution.(U//LES) Anyone with additional information or questions regarding this investigation isrequested to contact Rhode Island State Police Corporal David Gormly at 401-444-1064 ordavid.gormly@risp.gov. *If you have received this email with an unknown attachment or .dat file, please use the “openwith” option and use the program Adobe Reader to view. Keywords* Other Criminal Activity Click here to take product survey Massachusetts Subject: Previous identified Impostor with valid Mass License who was identified by Lowell PD Det. Burd has made it backinto U.S. after deportation.​     Hi Team, nice grab here by State Police out in Sturbridge during a traffic stop last Fridaynight. They were not fooled by the pretty good fraudulent "Real ID" Puerto Rico license.Running that OLN does come back to a PR License under that same Name however the Dob isdifferent. They were also able to get a facial recognition hit using our Fusion Center. TheFusion Center did a nice job getting a hit on two of his previous Mass Licenses under Impostoridentities. I hope the Fusion Center is thinking of rolling all our arrest/booking photos fromAFISR into the same facial recognition data base! Imagine this same type of data base NewEngland wide! This would be very bad for the bad guys! The access to this type of "ThirdThumb Print" my new term, roadside would be amazing. When me and Kathy saw the licensephoto we knew we has seen this Impostor before and "ICE Man Craig Hamel" recognized himright away as someone he had deported last year.     His real name is   and   still had a felony trafficking warrant out for hisarrest. This works out very well when the DA's office does not dismiss the drug case justbecause the suspect has been deported. All of this gave the Troopers more than enough totake this known impostor into custody. I'm hoping the Secure Communities alarm went offand he was grabbed the following Monday in court. The obvious questions is how was he ableto easily make it back into the U.S.? Does his employer, the drug cartel have a clear path ofentry we don't know about? He would make a great interview. This Lowell case was also oneof our first facial recognition hits using the agencies assigned to the Dominican Rep. Again, thisis the same facial recognition the ACLU and Somerville don't want us using! Are we really thatconcerned about these drug dealers alleged rights?James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PDIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program "Identifying the Impostor".

Burd has made itback into U.S. after deportation.​     From Bradley, take a look, both attachments the same I just cropped 2nd. Jay I don't havethe back!! but your right!James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PDIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program "Identifying the Impostor".

Subject: [Probable Spam] RE: Previous identified Impostor with valid Mass License who wasidentified by Lowell PD Det. Burd has made it back into U.S. after deportation. Jimmy, Is there an image of a seal anywhere on this document?  We just identified a subject here in Ohio,going through our counterparts in PR… (see attached).  Even the PR guys said it was  a pretty goodforgery. We are working a case now with the Ohio BMV, and our DBFTF, with direct ties to your area… can’tgive a lot of details, but we’ve arrested 3 this week, identified a handful of others, and sent Kathysome id’s to de-conflict.  She’s finding lots of impostors up your way… MA, MD, NJ, NY… Thank you, Bradley A. Subject: RE: Possible Fraudulent Identification - Request for Facial Recognition - DEA Boston OfficeSir, Upon reviewing the below email, it was discovered that a case already exists with our office, FRCase#   and MSP Case#  . The FR Case folder is inside the MSPfolder. There were no additional licenses/IDs discovered other than what is in the case and the same4 license numbers listed below in the email. Here are the findings from the case: · All 4 licenses have been suspended/revoked for fraud. Though S ,           since has been XXX’ed. The other 3 records have NOT been merged.·  was XXX’ed because the true owner living in IL sent proof and obtained a         Letter of Clearance from our RMV Office.· A criminal complaint was filed in 2010 by Tpr. Campinha under the MSP report, using John         Doe and the 4 aliases as AKA’s, but warrant is no longer active. Court decision in 2018 was a“NO PROS” by ADA. Unknown who showed up to court that day. Courts had no furtherinformation.· SA Jason Froio (617-565-8200) from Diplomatic Security Office looked into this person on 4-         5-07.· SA Dana Fiandaca (617-828-4571) from ICE had FR ran on a pic that matched with our         suspect on 1-26-12.· SA Craig Hamel (781-420-1030) from ICE/ERO had FR ran on one of the license (S )         pics that matched with our suspect on 4-17-15. Suspect is a 3 time re-entry illegal immigrant. Please let me know if you need any further information on this case. Respectfully Submitted, Tpr. Danny Malhotra #3642    Massachusetts State PoliceDivision of Homeland Security and PreparednessFraud Identification Unitnd10 Park Plaza 2  FloorBoston, MA 02116danish.malhotra2@dot.state.ma.usOffice: (857) 368-9500Desk: (857) 368-8622Cell: (857)-324-0411Fax: (857) 368-0649

body: Subject: Re: Facial recognition​     Hi Jason, interesting on the Mass permit with what appears to be a randomized SSN. I CC'dSgt Boyle from the fraud unit who can have one of his guys pull his application and check thedocuments. Does he have a III?  Kathy is in tomorrow (tuesday).     Craig - no hurry, wondering if you see anything, LPR with that randomized SSN is a chance. Icouldn't open Jason's attachment but he may have a straight out Impostor depending on thefacial rec hit.James Scott, Special Police Officer, Retired-Saugus MA PDIdentity Theft Expert/Instructor of the Universal Identity Theft Recognition Program "Identifying the Impostor".

Subject: Fwd: Facial recognition Hey guys, Been a little bit since we have emailed!  I’m checking into this male below Jose Lopez-polo. Pretty sure I know where he is staying in lowell.  Has a Lawrence warrant for all types offorgery as well as some NJ warrants for the same.  Getting info he is involved in all sorts offraud and more than likely an imposter.  Would like to see what else we can drum up beforetrying to arrest him.  Thanks for any help!  Jason Sent from my iPhoneBegin forwarded message:

body: (DOT); Thibault, Amy (POL); Smith, Eleanor (POL); Huber, Richard (POL); Brooks, Brian (POL); O"Leary, Sarah(POL)Subject: Re: Possible Fraudulent Identification - Request for Facial Recognition - DEA Boston OfficeAttachments: image001.pngMA10023062-FBI- .pdfMA10023062.pdfRegarding MA1 /FB    , aka  , AKA , aka,  .This individual has eighteen (18) arrests with fingerprint cards submitted to Mass State PoliceIdentification Section.We have mutilated fingerprints linked with non-mutilated fingerprints. Eleven (11) of those arrests were made after he intentionally mutilated his fingerprints in anattempt to hide his identity. First arrest with mutilated fingerprints 1/18/2006.On February 18, 2019, we became aware of his mutilated fingerprints. At that time they werenot linked with the non-mutilated files. He was added to our list of files with Mutilatedfingerprints - #779We searched them as latent prints and located two (2) addition files with the earlier arrestswith non-mutilated prints. The files were merged. We only located one (1) BOP record PCF:00002792088. There may be others that we couldnot find. Contact BOP for help with that. Attached please find Personal Summary showing the mutilated prints and the Mass RAP sheet.That is all we have at this time. Bcc: Riley, Judith (DOT)Subject: Fwd: Draft response to Herald Re: Facial RecognitionHi Registrar and Sara,Do you have any comments on Dave's draft below?Thanks,JudiSent from my iPhoneBegin forwarded message:
Jacquelyn (DOT)" <Jacquelyn.Goddard@dot.state.ma.us>Subject: RE: Draft response to Herald Re: Facial Recognition Hi Dave, I am looping in Registrar Deveney. Thanks, Judi

(DOT) <Patrick.Marvin@dot.state.ma.us>; Lavoie, Sara (DOT)<Sara.Lavoie@dot.state.ma.us>; Riley, Judith (DOT)<JudithReardon.Riley@dot.state.ma.us>Subject: Draft response to Herald Re: Facial Recognition Please review the below draft of statement/supplemental info for the Herald re:facial technology. This statement is being reviewed by the public safety commschain, MSP command, and RMV/DOT officials. Please send any comments backand I will review and synthesize any edits from the three groups. Dave ProcopioThe Massachusetts State Police utilize facial recognition technology, whenapplicable, to further criminal investigations, primarily our CommonwealthWatch Center as well as through our unit attached to the RMV. It is a valuabletool that can help investigators identify criminals and, by doing so, seek justicefor their victims and take offenders off the street before they commit anothercrime. The State Police unit at the RMV utilizes the technology to investigate suspectedlicense fraud. At the Watch Center, meanwhile, State Police analysts have thecapability to use facial recognition to help identify images of crime suspects at therequest of State Police units or other police agencies. Analysts can compareimages of unknown suspects against both the RMVdatabase and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit in and of itself is not a positiveidentification. Rather, it is an investigative lead that requires further follow up andvetting by case officers. This is part of the training our personnel receive, andwhen the Watch Center (part of our Fusion Center) performs a facial recognitionsearch for an outside agency, the following disclaimer is provided with theresults: The result of a face recognition search is provided by the CFC only as aninvestigative lead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVEIDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT. Any possible connection or involvementof any subject to the investigation must be determined through furtherinvestigation.As with any other investigative process or technology, use of facial recognitionsoftware may only be used for legitimate and clearly defined law enforcementpurposes, per MSP general investigative policies.Several recent examples of leads generated by MSP analysts through facialrecognition are below.Facial Recognition Examples:I-93 Public Safety Threat – Dirt Bike/ATV Operators• In February 2018, State Police Analysts assigned to the Commonwealth WatchCenter worked with Troopers out of the Cyber Crimes Unit to identify unknownparties involved in an incident that occurred on I-93 on Saturday, February 24,wherein more than twenty individuals created a traffic situation and public safetythreat by operating dirt bikes, ATVs, and other off-road vehicles on theexpressway. State Police made seven arrests on scene but many participantsremained unidentified. Utilizing open source investigative tools and FacialRecognition on videos and still photographs posted to social media from theevent, State Police Analysts were able to identify a number of additionalparticipants involved in the incident.Armed Robbery, Framingham, MA – Social Media IDs• In January, the Framingham Police Department requested assistance inidentifying four individuals believed to be involved in an armed robbery thatoccurred on January 14, 2019. Framingham PD was able to provide the webaddresses for social media profiles of the four suspects. Through a combination ofFacial Recognition and open source exploitation, State Police Analysts assignedto the Commonwealth Fusion Center were able to positively ID the suspects,despite several of them utilizing false names and not possessing MassachusettsLicenses or IDs. All four individuals have active warrants from various policedepartments, including several for other armed robberies.Road Rage Incident in Medford• In January, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by theMassachusetts State Police Medford Barracks regarding a road rage incident thatoccurred at Wellington Circle. The Trooper on scene provided cell phone video ofthe incident taken from inside the victim’s vehicle, depicting an unknown subjectapproaching and striking the vehicle. Facial Recognition conducted on a stillphotograph from the video returned a possible match to a Massachusetts Driver’sLicense or ID, which was providedwithin minutes to the investigator for follow-up.MSP Crime Gun Unit – Social Media IDs of Gang Members• In February, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contactedby theMassachusetts State Police Crime Gun Unit regarding an attempt to identify aseries of individuals on social media via Facial Recognition. The individuals,believed to be affiliated with a gang related crimes, were identified through acombination of Facial Recognition and open source exploitation of publiclyavailable information found on social media. In total, the identities ofapproximately 23 previously unidentified individuals were either confirmed viaphotograph/tattoo comparison, or tentatively identified via name, date of birth,and geographic profile combined with information publicly available on theirprofiles.Gang Identified for Out of State Agency• In March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by the the CriminalIntelligence Center from another eastern state regarding an attempt to identifyfour members of a street gang believed to have ties to Massachusetts throughpublicly accessible social media sources. Through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source investigation, all four suspects were positivelyidentified and their information shared with  State Police in the state from whichthe request originated pursuant to an ongoing investigation.MSP H-2 Identified Suspect with Felony Warrant(s)• Also in March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by theMassachusetts State Police Framingham Barracks regarding an attempt to identifyperson suspected of concealing his true identity from police. Facial Recognitionon a photograph taken by the investigating MSP Trooper on scene returned apossible match candidate. Subsequent investigation of the suspect corroboratedthe identification of Name/DOB, and also identified an existing felony warrantunder the suspect’s true name, resulting in the suspect’s arrest. Sent from my iPhone

Utilizing open sourceinvestigative tools and Facial Recognition on videos and stillphotographs posted to social media from the event, State PoliceAnalysts were able to identify a number of additional participantsinvolved in the incident.Armed Robbery, Framingham, MA – Social Media IDs• In January, the Framingham Police Department requested assistancein identifying four individuals believed to be involved in an armedrobbery that occurred on January 14, 2019. Framingham PD was ableto provide the web addresses for social media profiles of the foursuspects. Through a combination of Facial Recognition and opensource exploitation, State Police Analysts assigned to theCommonwealth Fusion Center were able to positively ID thesuspects, despite several of them utilizing false names and notpossessing Massachusetts Licenses or IDs. All four individuals haveactive warrants from various police departments, including severalfor other armed robberies.Road Rage Incident in Medford• In January, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by theMassachusetts State Police Medford Barracks regarding a road rageincident that occurred at Wellington Circle. The Trooper on sceneprovided cell phone video of the incident taken from inside thevictim’s vehicle, depicting an unknown subject approaching andstriking the vehicle. Facial Recognition conducted on a stillphotograph from the video returned a possible match to aMassachusetts Driver’s License or ID, which was providedwithinminutes to the investigator for follow-up.MSP Crime Gun Unit – Social Media IDs of Gang Members• In February, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contactedby theMassachusetts State Police Crime Gun Unit regarding an attempt toidentify a series of individuals on social media via FacialRecognition. The individuals, believed to be affiliated with a gangrelated crimes, were identified through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source exploitation of publicly availableinformation found on social media. In total, the identities ofapproximately 23 previously unidentified individuals were eitherconfirmed via photograph/tattoo comparison, or tentatively identifiedvia name, date of birth, and geographic profile combined withinformation publicly available on their profiles.Gang Identified for Out of State Agency• In March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by thethe Criminal Intelligence Center from another eastern state regardingan attempt to identify four members of a street gang believed to haveties to Massachusetts through publicly accessible social mediasources. Through a combination of Facial Recognition and opensource investigation, all four suspects were positively identified andtheir information shared with  State Police in the state from which therequest originated pursuant to an ongoing investigation.MSP H-2 Identified Suspect with Felony Warrant(s)• Also in March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted bythe Massachusetts State Police Framingham Barracks regarding anattempt to identify person suspected of concealing his true identityfrom police. Facial Recognition on a photograph taken by theinvestigating MSP Trooper on scene returned a possible matchcandidate. Subsequent investigation of the suspect corroborated theidentification of Name/DOB, and also identified an existing felonywarrant under the suspect’s true name, resulting in the suspect’sarrest. Sent from my iPhone

Subject: RE: deadline Friday—-HeraldFacial RecognitionHi—just trying to get all asks in one place, looks like 2 items for us. 1) Questions for RMV to answer – I drafted some responses below. Needs work!   I'm assuming the RMV makes these photos available to police if they ask for it? The1)RMV makes digitized images of credential holders available to law enforcement so lawenforcement may confirm the veracity of the credentials presented to them and theidentity of the individuals before them.Are there any steps the RMV takes to protect the privacy of individuals? Thedissemination of RMV held images is strictly controlled by the federal driver privacyprotection act. (As an example, the DPPA prohibits the RMV from releasing licenseimage photos to the media.)  Also, besides the RMV, does the DOT use facial recognition in any way? No. 2) Any RMV comments to Procopio statement. My suggestion/edits are highlighted. The Massachusetts State Police utilize (might change utilize to may access) facial recognitiontechnology, when applicable, to further criminal investigations, primarily our CommonwealthWatch Center as well as through our unit attached to the RMV. It is a valuable tool that canhelp investigators identify criminals and, by doing so, seek justice for their victims and takeoffenders off the street before they commit another crime. The State Police unit at the RMV utilizes the technology to investigate suspected driver’slicense and identity fraud. At the Watch Center, meanwhile, State Police analysts have thecapability to use facial recognition to help identify images of crime suspects at the request ofState Police units or other police agencies. Analysts can compare images of unknown suspectsagainst both the RMV database and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit (suggest changing to hit to potential match,not hit) in and of itself is not a positive identification. Rather, it is an investigative lead thatrequires further follow up and vetting by case officers. This is part of the training ourpersonnel receive, and when the Watch Center (part of our Fusion Center) performs a facialrecognition search for an outside agency, the following disclaimer is provided with theresults: The result of a face recognition search is provided by the CFC only as an investigativelead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT.Any possible connection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must be determinedthrough further investigation.As with any other investigative process or technology, use of facial recognition software mayonly be used for legitimate and clearly defined law enforcement purposes, per MSP generalinvestigative policies. Several recent examples of leads generated by MSP analysts through facial recognition arebelow. I have no comment on the examples

body: McGlinchey, Madison (DOT)Subject: FW: deadline at noon today —-Herald story on Facial RecognitionDavid and Brendan,Re: Herald questions on facial recognition use.Please see below for the RMV suggested edits to David’s draft comment and in red font  RMVanswers to RMV questions. Boston Herald needs comment by noon. Thanks,Jacque DRAFT at 9:45 a.m. Questions for RMV to answer: Q: I'm assuming the RMV makes these photos available to police if they ask for it?The RMV makes digitized images of credential holders available to law enforcement solaw enforcement may confirm the veracity of the credentials presented to them.Q: Are there any steps the RMV takes to protect the privacy of individuals? Thedissemination of RMV held images is strictly controlled by the federal driver privacyprotection act. (As an example, the DPPA prohibits the RMV from releasing licenseimage photos to the media.)  Q: Also, besides the RMV, does the DOT use facial recognition in any way?MassDOT does not use facial recognition beyond the Registry’s use which is strictlycontrolled by the federal driver privacy protection act and policy guidelines. 2) Any RMV comments to David Procopio statement?. RMV suggested edits in yellow highlights. The Massachusetts State Police utilize (might change utilize to may access) facial recognitiontechnology, when applicable, to further criminal investigations, primarily our CommonwealthWatch Center as well as through our unit attached to the RMV. It is a valuable tool that canhelp investigators identify criminals and, by doing so, seek justice for their victims and takeoffenders off the street before they commit another crime. At the Watch Center, meanwhile, State Police analysts have thecapability to use facial recognition to help identify images of crime suspects at the request ofState Police units or other police agencies. Analysts can compare images of unknown suspectsagainst both the RMV database and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit (suggest changing to hit to potential match,not hit) in and of itself is not a positive identification. Rather, it is an investigative lead thatrequires further follow up and vetting by case officers. This is part of the training ourpersonnel receive, and when the Watch Center (part of our Fusion Center) performs a facialrecognition search for an outside agency, the following disclaimer is provided with theresults: The result of a face recognition search is provided by the CFC only as an investigativelead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT.Any possible connection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must be determinedthrough further investigation.As with any other investigative process or technology, use of facial recognition software mayonly be used for legitimate and clearly defined law enforcement purposes, per MSP generalinvestigative policies. Several recent examples of leads generated by MSP analysts through facial recognition arebelow.

any subject to theinvestigation must be determined through further investigation.As with any other investigative process or technology, use of facialrecognition software may only be used for legitimate and clearlydefined law enforcement purposes, per MSP general investigativepolicies.Several recent examples of leads generated by MSP analysts throughfacial recognition are below.Facial Recognition Examples:I-93 Public Safety Threat – Dirt Bike/ATV Operators• In February 2018, State Police Analysts assigned to theCommonwealth Watch Center worked with Troopers out of theCyber Crimes Unit to identify unknown parties involved in anincident that occurred on I-93 on Saturday, February 24, whereinmore than twenty individuals created a traffic situation and publicsafety threat by operating dirt bikes, ATVs, and other off-roadvehicles on the expressway. State Police made seven arrests on scenebut many participants remained unidentified. Utilizing open sourceinvestigative tools and Facial Recognition on videos and stillphotographs posted to social media from the event, State PoliceAnalysts were able to identify a number of additional participantsinvolved in the incident.Armed Robbery, Framingham, MA – Social Media IDs• In January, the Framingham Police Department requested assistancein identifying four individuals believed to be involved in an armedrobbery that occurred on January 14, 2019. Framingham PD was ableto provide the web addresses for social media profiles of the foursuspects. Through a combination of Facial Recognition and opensource exploitation, State Police Analysts assigned to theCommonwealth Fusion Center were able to positively ID thesuspects, despite several of them utilizing false names and notpossessing Massachusetts Licenses or IDs. All four individuals haveactive warrants from various police departments, including severalfor other armed robberies.Road Rage Incident in Medford• In January, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by theMassachusetts State Police Medford Barracks regarding a road rageincident that occurred at Wellington Circle. The Trooper on sceneprovided cell phone video of the incident taken from inside thevictim’s vehicle, depicting an unknown subject approaching andstriking the vehicle. Facial Recognition conducted on a stillphotograph from the video returned a possible match to aMassachusetts Driver’s License or ID, which was providedwithinminutes to the investigator for follow-up.MSP Crime Gun Unit – Social Media IDs of Gang Members• In February, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contactedby theMassachusetts State Police Crime Gun Unit regarding an attempt toidentify a series of individuals on social media via FacialRecognition. The individuals, believed to be affiliated with a gangrelated crimes, were identified through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source exploitation of publicly availableinformation found on social media. In total, the identities ofapproximately 23 previously unidentified individuals were eitherconfirmed via photograph/tattoo comparison, or tentatively identifiedvia name, date of birth, and geographic profile combined withinformation publicly available on their profiles.Gang Identified for Out of State Agency• In March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted by thethe Criminal Intelligence Center from another eastern state regardingan attempt to identify four members of a street gang believed to haveties to Massachusetts through publicly accessible social mediasources. Through a combination of Facial Recognition and opensource investigation, all four suspects were positively identified andtheir information shared with  State Police in the state from which therequest originated pursuant to an ongoing investigation.MSP H-2 Identified Suspect with Felony Warrant(s)• Also in March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center was contacted bythe Massachusetts State Police Framingham Barracks regarding anattempt to identify person suspected of concealing his true identityfrom police. Facial Recognition on a photograph taken by theinvestigating MSP Trooper on scene returned a possible matchcandidate. Subsequent investigation of the suspect corroborated theidentification of Name/DOB, and also identified an existing felonywarrant under the suspect’s true name, resulting in the suspect’sarrest. Sent from my iPhone

body: Huber, Maxwell (DOT); McGlinchey, Madison (DOT)Subject: Re: deadline at noon today —-Herald story on Facial RecognitionThank you Sent from my iPhoneOn Jun 7, 2019, at 9:43 AM, Goddard, Jacquelyn (DOT)<Jacquelyn.Goddard@dot.state.ma.us> wrote:David and Brendan,Re: Herald questions on facial recognition use.Please see below for the RMV suggested edits to David’s draft comment and in redfont  RMV answers to RMV questions. Boston Herald needs comment by noon. Thanks,Jacque DRAFT at 9:45 a.m. Questions for RMV to answer: Q: I'm assuming the RMV makes these photos available to police if theyask for it? The RMV makes digitized images of credential holders available tolaw enforcement so law enforcement may confirm the veracity of thecredentials presented to them.Q: Are there any steps the RMV takes to protect the privacy ofindividuals? The dissemination of RMV held images is strictly controlled bythe federal driver privacy protection act. (As an example, the DPPAprohibits the RMV from releasing license image photos to the media.)  Q: Also, besides the RMV, does the DOT use facial recognition in anyway? MassDOT does not use facial recognition beyond the Registry’s use whichis strictly controlled by the federal driver privacy protection act and policyguidelines. 2) Any RMV comments to David Procopio statement?. RMV suggested edits in yellowhighlights. The Massachusetts State Police utilize (might change utilize to may access) facialrecognition technology, when applicable, to further criminal investigations,primarily our Commonwealth Watch Center as well as through our unit attachedto the RMV. It is a valuable tool that can help investigators identify criminals and,by doing so, seek justice for their victims and take offenders off the street beforethey commit another crime. The State Police unit at the RMV utilizes the technology to investigate suspecteddriver’s license and identity fraud. At the Watch Center, meanwhile, State Policeanalysts have the capability to use facial recognition to help identify images ofcrime suspects at the request of State Police units or other police agencies.Analysts can compare images of unknown suspects against both the RMVdatabase and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit (suggest changing to hit topotential match, not hit) in and of itself is not a positive identification. Rather, it isan investigative lead that requires further follow up and vetting by case officers.This is part of the training our personnel receive, and when the Watch Center(part of our Fusion Center) performs a facial recognition search for an outsideagency, the following disclaimer is provided with the results: The result of a facerecognition search is provided by the CFC only as an investigative lead and ISNOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT.Any possible connection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must bedetermined through further investigation.As with any other investigative process or technology, use of facial recognitionsoftware may only be used for legitimate and clearly defined law enforcementpurposes, per MSP general investigative policies. Several recent examples of leads generated by MSP analysts through facialrecognition are below.

<david.procopio@pol.state.ma.us> <Jacquelyn.Goddard@dot.state.ma.us>; Marvin, Patrick(DOT) <Patrick.Marvin@dot.state.ma.us>; Lavoie, Sara (DOT)<Sara.Lavoie@dot.state.ma.us>; Riley, Judith (DOT)<JudithReardon.Riley@dot.state.ma.us>Subject: Draft response to Herald Re: Facial Recognition Please review the below draft of statement/supplementalinfo for the Herald re: facial technology. This statementis being reviewed by the public safety comms chain,MSP command, and RMV/DOT officials. Please sendany comments back and I will review and synthesize anyedits from the three groups. Dave ProcopioThe Massachusetts State Police utilize facial recognitiontechnology, when applicable, to further criminalinvestigations, primarily our Commonwealth WatchCenter as well as through our unit attached to theRMV. It is a valuable tool that can help investigatorsidentify criminals and, by doing so, seek justice for theirvictims and take offenders off the street before theycommit another crime. The State Police unit at the RMV utilizes the technologyto investigate suspected license fraud. At the WatchCenter, meanwhile, State Police analysts have thecapability to use facial recognition to help identifyimages of crime suspects at the request of State Policeunits or other police agencies. Analysts can compareimages of unknown suspects against both the RMVdatabase and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit in andof itself is not a positive identification. Rather, it is aninvestigative lead that requires further follow up andvetting by case officers. This is part of the training ourpersonnel receive, and when the Watch Center (part ofour Fusion Center) performs a facial recognition searchfor an outside agency, the following disclaimer isprovided with the results: The result of a facerecognition search is provided by the CFC only as aninvestigative lead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED APOSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT. Anypossible connection or involvement of any subject to theinvestigation must be determined through furtherinvestigation.As with any other investigative process or technology,use of facial recognition software may only be used forlegitimate and clearly defined law enforcement purposes,per MSP general investigative policies.Several recent examples of leads generated by MSPanalysts through facial recognition are below.Facial Recognition Examples:I-93 Public Safety Threat – Dirt Bike/ATV Operators• In February 2018, State Police Analysts assigned to theCommonwealth Watch Center worked with Troopers outof the Cyber Crimes Unit to identify unknown partiesinvolved in an incident that occurred on I-93 onSaturday, February 24, wherein more than twentyindividuals created a traffic situation and public safetythreat by operating dirt bikes, ATVs, and other off-roadvehicles on the expressway. State Police made sevenarrests on scene but many participants remainedunidentified. Utilizing open source investigative toolsand Facial Recognition on videos and still photographsposted to social media from the event, State PoliceAnalysts were able to identify a number of additionalparticipants involved in the incident.Armed Robbery, Framingham, MA – Social Media IDs• In January, the Framingham Police Departmentrequested assistance in identifying four individualsbelieved to be involved in an armed robbery thatoccurred on January 14, 2019. Framingham PD was ableto provide the web addresses for social media profiles ofthe four suspects. Through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source exploitation, State PoliceAnalysts assigned to the Commonwealth Fusion Centerwere able to positively ID the suspects, despite several ofthem utilizing false names and not possessingMassachusetts Licenses or IDs. All four individuals haveactive warrants from various police departments,including several for other armed robberies.Road Rage Incident in Medford• In January, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontacted by the Massachusetts State Police MedfordBarracks regarding a road rage incident that occurred atWellington Circle. The Trooper on scene provided cellphone video of the incident taken from inside thevictim’s vehicle, depicting an unknown subjectapproaching and striking the vehicle. Facial Recognitionconducted on a still photograph from the video returneda possible match to a Massachusetts Driver’s License orID, which was providedwithin minutes to theinvestigator for follow-up.MSP Crime Gun Unit – Social Media IDs of GangMembers• In February, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontactedby the Massachusetts State Police Crime GunUnit regarding an attempt to identify a series ofindividuals on social media via Facial Recognition. Theindividuals, believed to be affiliated with a gang relatedcrimes, were identified through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source exploitation of publiclyavailable information found on social media. In total, theidentities of approximately 23 previously unidentifiedindividuals were either confirmed via photograph/tattoocomparison, or tentatively identified via name, date ofbirth, and geographic profile combined with informationpublicly available on their profiles.Gang Identified for Out of State Agency• In March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontacted by the the Criminal Intelligence Center fromanother eastern state regarding an attempt to identify fourmembers of a street gang believed to have ties toMassachusetts through publicly accessible social mediasources. Through a combination of Facial Recognitionand open source investigation, all four suspects werepositively identified and their information sharedwith  State Police in the state from which the requestoriginated pursuant to an ongoing investigation.MSP H-2 Identified Suspect with Felony Warrant(s)• Also in March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontacted by the Massachusetts State Police FraminghamBarracks regarding an attempt to identify personsuspected of concealing his true identity from police.Facial Recognition on a photograph taken by theinvestigating MSP Trooper on scene returned a possiblematch candidate. Subsequent investigation of the suspectcorroborated the identification of Name/DOB, and alsoidentified an existing felony warrant under the suspect’strue name, resulting in the suspect’s arrest. Sent from my iPhone

body: Rob (DOT); Huber, Maxwell (DOT); McGlinchey, Madison (DOT)Subject: Re: deadline at noon today —-Herald story on Facial Recognition Thank you Sent from my iPhoneOn Jun 7, 2019, at 9:43 AM, Goddard, Jacquelyn (DOT)<Jacquelyn.Goddard@dot.state.ma.us> wrote:David and Brendan,Re: Herald questions on facial recognition use.Please see below for the RMV suggested edits to David’s draft comment and in redfont  RMV answers to RMV questions. Boston Herald needs comment by noon. Thanks,Jacque DRAFT at 9:45 a.m. Questions for RMV to answer: Q: I'm assuming the RMV makes these photos available to police if theyask for it? The RMV makes digitized images of credential holders available tolaw enforcement so law enforcement may confirm the veracity of thecredentials presented to them.Q: Are there any steps the RMV takes to protect the privacy ofindividuals? The dissemination of RMV held images is strictly controlled bythe federal driver privacy protection act. (As an example, the DPPAprohibits the RMV from releasing license image photos to the media.)  Q: Also, besides the RMV, does the DOT use facial recognition in anyway? MassDOT does not use facial recognition beyond the Registry’s use whichis strictly controlled by the federal driver privacy protection act and policyguidelines. 2) Any RMV comments to David Procopio statement?. RMV suggested edits in yellowhighlights. The Massachusetts State Police utilize (might change utilize to may access) facialrecognition technology, when applicable, to further criminal investigations,primarily our Commonwealth Watch Center as well as through our unit attachedto the RMV. It is a valuable tool that can help investigators identify criminals and,by doing so, seek justice for their victims and take offenders off the street beforethey commit another crime. The State Police unit at the RMV utilizes the technology to investigate suspecteddriver’s license and identity fraud. At the Watch Center, meanwhile, State Policeanalysts have the capability to use facial recognition to help identify images ofcrime suspects at the request of State Police units or other police agencies.Analysts can compare images of unknown suspects against both the RMVdatabase and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit (suggest changing to hit topotential match, not hit) in and of itself is not a positive identification. Rather, it isan investigative lead that requires further follow up and vetting by case officers.This is part of the training our personnel receive, and when the Watch Center(part of our Fusion Center) performs a facial recognition search for an outsideagency, the following disclaimer is provided with the results: The result of a facerecognition search is provided by the CFC only as an investigative lead and ISNOT TO BE CONSIDERED A POSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT.Any possible connection or involvement of any subject to the investigation must bedetermined through further investigation.As with any other investigative process or technology, use of facial recognitionsoftware may only be used for legitimate and clearly defined law enforcementpurposes, per MSP general investigative policies. Several recent examples of leads generated by MSP analysts through facialrecognition are below.

<david.procopio@pol.state.ma.us> <Jacquelyn.Goddard@dot.state.ma.us>; Marvin, Patrick(DOT) <Patrick.Marvin@dot.state.ma.us>; Lavoie, Sara (DOT)<Sara.Lavoie@dot.state.ma.us>; Riley, Judith (DOT)<JudithReardon.Riley@dot.state.ma.us>Subject: Draft response to Herald Re: Facial Recognition Please review the below draft of statement/supplementalinfo for the Herald re: facial technology. This statementis being reviewed by the public safety comms chain,MSP command, and RMV/DOT officials. Please sendany comments back and I will review and synthesize anyedits from the three groups. Dave ProcopioThe Massachusetts State Police utilize facial recognitiontechnology, when applicable, to further criminalinvestigations, primarily our Commonwealth WatchCenter as well as through our unit attached to theRMV. It is a valuable tool that can help investigatorsidentify criminals and, by doing so, seek justice for theirvictims and take offenders off the street before theycommit another crime. The State Police unit at the RMV utilizes the technologyto investigate suspected license fraud. At the WatchCenter, meanwhile, State Police analysts have thecapability to use facial recognition to help identifyimages of crime suspects at the request of State Policeunits or other police agencies. Analysts can compareimages of unknown suspects against both the RMVdatabase and open-source social media.It is important to note that a facial recognition hit in andof itself is not a positive identification. Rather, it is aninvestigative lead that requires further follow up andvetting by case officers. This is part of the training ourpersonnel receive, and when the Watch Center (part ofour Fusion Center) performs a facial recognition searchfor an outside agency, the following disclaimer isprovided with the results: The result of a facerecognition search is provided by the CFC only as aninvestigative lead and IS NOT TO BE CONSIDERED APOSITIVE IDENTIFICATION OF ANY SUBJECT. Anypossible connection or involvement of any subject to theinvestigation must be determined through furtherinvestigation.As with any other investigative process or technology,use of facial recognition software may only be used forlegitimate and clearly defined law enforcement purposes,per MSP general investigative policies.Several recent examples of leads generated by MSPanalysts through facial recognition are below.Facial Recognition Examples:I-93 Public Safety Threat – Dirt Bike/ATV Operators• In February 2018, State Police Analysts assigned to theCommonwealth Watch Center worked with Troopers outof the Cyber Crimes Unit to identify unknown partiesinvolved in an incident that occurred on I-93 onSaturday, February 24, wherein more than twentyindividuals created a traffic situation and public safetythreat by operating dirt bikes, ATVs, and other off-roadvehicles on the expressway. State Police made sevenarrests on scene but many participants remainedunidentified. Utilizing open source investigative toolsand Facial Recognition on videos and still photographsposted to social media from the event, State PoliceAnalysts were able to identify a number of additionalparticipants involved in the incident.Armed Robbery, Framingham, MA – Social Media IDs• In January, the Framingham Police Departmentrequested assistance in identifying four individualsbelieved to be involved in an armed robbery thatoccurred on January 14, 2019. Framingham PD was ableto provide the web addresses for social media profiles ofthe four suspects. Through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source exploitation, State PoliceAnalysts assigned to the Commonwealth Fusion Centerwere able to positively ID the suspects, despite several ofthem utilizing false names and not possessingMassachusetts Licenses or IDs. All four individuals haveactive warrants from various police departments,including several for other armed robberies.Road Rage Incident in Medford• In January, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontacted by the Massachusetts State Police MedfordBarracks regarding a road rage incident that occurred atWellington Circle. The Trooper on scene provided cellphone video of the incident taken from inside thevictim’s vehicle, depicting an unknown subjectapproaching and striking the vehicle. Facial Recognitionconducted on a still photograph from the video returneda possible match to a Massachusetts Driver’s License orID, which was providedwithin minutes to theinvestigator for follow-up.MSP Crime Gun Unit – Social Media IDs of GangMembers• In February, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontactedby the Massachusetts State Police Crime GunUnit regarding an attempt to identify a series ofindividuals on social media via Facial Recognition. Theindividuals, believed to be affiliated with a gang relatedcrimes, were identified through a combination of FacialRecognition and open source exploitation of publiclyavailable information found on social media. In total, theidentities of approximately 23 previously unidentifiedindividuals were either confirmed via photograph/tattoocomparison, or tentatively identified via name, date ofbirth, and geographic profile combined with informationpublicly available on their profiles.Gang Identified for Out of State Agency• In March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontacted by the the Criminal Intelligence Center fromanother eastern state regarding an attempt to identify fourmembers of a street gang believed to have ties toMassachusetts through publicly accessible social mediasources. Through a combination of Facial Recognitionand open source investigation, all four suspects werepositively identified and their information sharedwith  State Police in the state from which the requestoriginated pursuant to an ongoing investigation.MSP H-2 Identified Suspect with Felony Warrant(s)• Also in March, the Commonwealth Fusion Center wascontacted by the Massachusetts State Police FraminghamBarracks regarding an attempt to identify personsuspected of concealing his true identity from police.Facial Recognition on a photograph taken by theinvestigating MSP Trooper on scene returned a possiblematch candidate. Subsequent investigation of the suspectcorroborated the identification of Name/DOB, and alsoidentified an existing felony warrant under the suspect’strue name, resulting in the suspect’s arrest. Sent from my iPhone

Subject: deadline at noon today —-Herald story on Facial RecognitionHi David, Do you have any comments on the RMV’s draft responses below? Questions for RMV to answer: I'm assuming the RMV makes these photos available to police if they ask for it?The RMV makes digitized images of credential holders available to law enforcement so lawenforcement may confirm the veracity of the credentials presented to them.Are there any steps the RMV takes to protect the privacy of individuals?The dissemination of RMV held images is strictly controlled by the federal driver privacy protectionact. (As an example, the DPPA prohibits the RMV from releasing license image photos to the media.) Also, besides the RMV, does the DOT use facial recognition in any way?MassDOT does not use facial recognition beyond the Registry’s use which is strictly controlled by thefederal driver privacy protection act and policy guidelines.Thanks, Judi
